steps.title: Understanding Cell References
steps.content:
Cell References in Excel

Before we dive into calculations, let's understand how to reference cells in Excel. Each cell has a unique address made up of its column letter and row number. For example, the first cell is A1, the cell below it is A2, and the cell to its right is B1.

Navigating and Selecting Cells

There are several ways to select cells in Excel:

  • Arrow Keys: Use the keyboard arrow keys to move between cells one at a time.
  • Direct Navigation: Type a cell reference in the Name Box (top-left corner) and press Enter to jump to that cell.
  • Mouse Selection: Click any cell to select it, or click and drag to select multiple cells.
  • Shift + Click: Click a starting cell, hold Shift, then click an end cell to select all cells between them.

Working with Cell Ranges

A range refers to a group of selected cells. When writing a range, use a colon (:) between two cell references to include all cells between them. For example, A1:B1 includes cells A1 and B1, while A1:A5 includes cells A1 through A5.

steps.title: Basic Math Operations
steps.content:
Performing Basic Math in Excel

Excel supports all basic math operations using these symbols:

  • Addition: +
  • Subtraction: -
  • Multiplication: *
  • Division: /

How to Perform a Calculation

  1. Click the cell where you want the result.
  2. Type = (equals sign) to start the formula.
  3. Click the first cell you want to use.
  4. Type the math operator (+, -, *, or /).
  5. Click the second cell.
  6. Press Enter.

For example, to add cells A1 and B1, you would type:

=A1+B1

You can also hold down Ctrl and click to select the exact cell if you don't want to type the cells in.
